thread.title: Crazy golfer hits ball from a boulder balancing 3,245ft above the ocean
thread.title_full: Crazy golfer hits ball from a boulder balancing 3,245ft above the ocean | Daily Mail Online

author: Katie Amey for MailOnline
title: Crazy golfer hits ball from a boulder balancing 3,245ft above the ocean
text:
26 shares 7
View
comments
Anyone who says golf isn't an exciting game has not seen this shocking video.
Sigurdur Hauksson, an Iceland native and avid golfer, showed off his skills bouncing a golf ball on the face of his wedge iron.
And while this is a fun trick for anyone - just ask Tiger Woods - it was infinitely more impressive considering Hauksson performed it 3,425 feet above sea level, while standing on top of a boulder.
Sigurdur Hauksson, an Iceland native and avid golfer, showed off his skills bouncing a golf ball on the face of his wedge iron - thousands of feet above a fjord
After bouncing the ball for several seconds, the adventurous sportsman ultimately fires a shot off from his club, which quickly disappears into the abyss.
Kjeragbolten, the boulder where this stunt took place, is a popular tourist site in Rogaland, Norway, as it's accessible without any climbing equipment.
 PICTURED: Father-of-eight American Airlines pilot who died... Classical musician 'threatened with arrest and patted down... The yacht that's powered by the sun: On board the world's... Heathrow Airport releases new images of proposed Â£19billion... 26 shares The boulder, which measures five metres cubed, is wedged in between a crevasse on Mount Kjerag in Norway and is a popular spot for BASE jumping.
For practicing one's golf swing, however, less so.
He also took an impressive trick shot, firing the golf ball out into the abyss from a boulder wedged in between a mountain pass
Hauksson posted his trick shot on Instagram, writing: 'To the 19th hole! Made my heart go a little bit wild, only 989m above the ocean (3,245ft).'
Golf Digest , while impressed with his ability to balance, also notes that 'his swing at the end is rather feeble, with no weight shift.'
'Must have something to do with the drop to the fjord below should he have made a single false step.'
Read more: http://www.golfdigest.com/story/man-stands-on-a-boulder-wedged-3245-feet-above-a-fjord-and-bounces-a-ball-on-a-wedge
